creator: eroy@us.ibm.com
text:
With two namespaces, each one with its schema and each one importing the
other, Xerces just loops and crashes.
AFAIK, the recursive inclusion of the schemas is allowed by the spec. The
definitions are not recursive, it's just that the namespaces need definitions 
included in each other.

test files:
schemas:

<schema xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/10/XMLSchema"
        xmlns:first="http://www.first.test"
        xmlns:second="http://www.second.test"
        targetNamespace="http://www.first.test"
        elementFormDefault="qualified">

    <!-- import the second namespace -->
    <import namespace="http://www.second.test" schemaLocation="loop2.xsd"/>

  <element name="test" type="string"/>

</schema>

and

<schema xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/10/XMLSchema"
        xmlns:first="http://www.first.test"
        xmlns:second="http://www.second.test"
        targetNamespace="http://www.second.test"
        elementFormDefault="qualified">

    <!-- import the first namespace -->
    <import namespace="http://www.first.test" schemaLocation="loop1.xsd"/>

  <element name="unused" type="string"/>

</schema>

and instance:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<test xmlns="http://www.first.test"
      xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.first.test loop1.xsd"
      xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2000/10/XMLSchema-instance"/>

This bug is fixed in that the parser no longer recurses indefinitely when 
presented with schemas such as your example.  In fact, it validates your 
example without errors.  But, in the near-term at least, we won't be able to 
support schemas which mutually import each other *and* refer to each other's 
components; this is something that's just beyond the capabilities of our 
architecture at the moment.  We're trying to find out for certain whether this 
is indeed legal; if it is, it'll make it into our list of limitations for now.
